awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: Computational and Interactive Design of Soft Growing Robot Manipulators
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the development of new soft robot manipulators that can assist people with limited physical abilities in their activities of daily living in the home. Soft robots are made of flexible and stretchable materials configured to increase human safety, lower cost, and mechanically adapt to their environments, which are significant advantages compared to traditional, rigid robots. However, today's soft robots are far from capable of performing household manipulation tasks; they have limited dexterity and cannot handle the weight of many objects encountered in daily life. This award supports research to develop novel mechanisms and design tools in order to create soft robots that seamlessly integrate into homes and provide needed assistance. This project aims to improve human health and quality of life by (1) assisting people with limited physical abilities in their homes, (2) lowering the cost of robot manipulators, toward making robots accessible to a wide spectrum of users, and (3) promoting human safety through controllable mechanical compliance and robustness. These features are important to improve equity in access to technology, especially in scenarios where physical distancing between humans is required. This interdisciplinary project integrates mechanical engineering and computer science, and the project will educate a diverse group of students in classes and research in order to broaden participation in STEM.

This project will develop a modular set of new soft robot components that capitalize on previously developed steerable, tip-extending inflated beams: continuum links, variable stiffness control, and variable discrete joints. Each component contributes a valuable capability toward 3D manipulation. Because the process of specifying and combining these components in order to create a robot to achieve a particular task is too difficult for human designers to effectively navigate, the research team will create simulation and planning software. This software will enable a computational design process considering inverse kinematics, inverse dynamics, and trajectory optimization to develop both the overall design and the real-time control strategy. In the simulation and planning environment, users who are not robotics experts will be able to specify the critical tasks, test the ability of the robot to achieve the specified tasks as well as new tasks, and influence the design to be compatible with their needs. The effectiveness of this approach will be demonstrated through user studies and the implementation of a variety of inflated-beam soft 3D robot manipulators that perform different household tasks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: Bldg. 550, Room 107, 416 Escondido Mall, Stanford University

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
For people with limited physical abilities due to age or injury, there is significant motivation to provide robots that can assist in activities of daily living in home environments. Compared to traditional rigid robots, soft continuum manipulators hold great promise for this purpose due to their potential to increase human safety, lower cost, and mechanically adapt to their environments. Yet, today's soft robots are far from capable of performing household manipulation tasks; the same mechanical properties that provide them with "embodied intelligence" also limit their dexterity and prevent them from handling relevant payloads. Robot designers also lack the tools necessary to optimize actuation of the effectively infinite degrees of freedom of soft continuum robots. Moreover, given the wide variety of manipulation tasks that people might want a soft robot to perform, we argue that an interactive human-in-the-loop design process could achieve the most useful designs. The goal of this project was to integrate novel soft robot mechanisms, computational design tools, and an interactive design methodology in order to create ubiquitous soft robots that seamlessly integrate into human homes and provide needed assistance.

In this project, we successfully designed new soft robot manipulator systems that have the potential to provide key manipulation capabilities both inside and outside the home. We developed a method for stiffening soft robot manipulators to allow them to accomplish a wider variety of tasks and achieve varied shapes. We created a new set of interaction paradigms between a human and a remote soft-growing robot manipulator, with demonstrations in both real and simulated scenarios. We enabled extrinsic manipulation in contact-rich environments using a library of robust short-horizon, goal-conditioned primitive policies, along with a framework to compose state constraints stemming from contacts specifications of each primitive. We also developed pneumatic platforms and control methods that enable flying soft robot manipulators to extend human reach. We also built cognitive systems for human-robot interaction, including predictive models for human indoor navigation and manipulation. 

Intellectual Merit: This project integrated mechanical design, computational design, modeling, planning, and control to create novel soft robots and a methodology to improve and expand access to robot design. By combining advantages of both soft and rigid manipulators, the resulting novel 3D manipulators have unprecedented capabilities related to activities of daily living. This work was enabled by the combined expertise of PI Okamura (soft robot design and human-robot interaction) and co-I Liu (computer animation, physics simulation, and optimal control).

Broader Impacts: This project leads to impacts on human health and quality of life by (1) assisting people with limited physical abilities in their homes, (2) lowering the cost of robot manipulators, toward making ubiquitous robots accessible to a wide spectrum of users, and (3) promoting human safety through controllable mechanical compliance and robustness. The results have been disseminated via educational resources, demonstration of new soft robot capabilities, and open-source software. Outreach programs, public lab tours, and mentoring of graduate students, undergraduates, and high school students have broadened participation in engineering.

 


Last Modified: 04/09/2025
Modified by: Allison M Okamura

Images (1 of )
  • Soft Robot Manipulator: A soft-growing robot manipulator can extend from a base container by growing its body and steering it towards items in the workspace to perform pick-and-place tasks by means of a soft-magnetic gripper mounted at its tip (Stroppa et al. 2023).
    Allison Okamura, Fabio Stroppa
    Copyrighted
    Allison M Okamura
    Soft Robot Manipulator
  • We developed a hybrid system that combines VR and motion capture devices to enable interactive navigation and manipulation in realistically rendered and physically simulated virtual environments.
    Karen Liu
    Copyrighted
    Allison M Okamura
    Interactive design of soft robots using VR technologies
  • We trained a conditional diffusion model to predict the navigation path and contact locations on the target object based on a given language command. This information helps guide soft vine robots in navigating and manipulating objects in an indoor environment.
    Karen Liu
    Copyrighted
    Allison M Okamura
    Learning Navigation and Manipulation from Humans
  • Soft robot manipulators with the capability for growth, stiffness control, and discrete joints have the potential to approach the dexterity of traditional robot arms, while improving safety, lowering cost, and providing an increased workspace, with potential application in home environments.
    Ioannis Exarchos, Allison Okamura, Brian Do, and Karen Liu
    Copyrighted
    Allison M Okamura
    Task-Specific Design Optimization for Soft Robots
por.por_txt_cntn:
For people with limited physical abilities due to age or injury, there is significant motivation to provide robots that can assist in activities of daily living in home environments. Compared to traditional rigid robots, soft continuum manipulators hold great promise for this purpose due to their potential to increase human safety, lower cost, and mechanically adapt to their environments. Yet, today's soft robots are far from capable of performing household manipulation tasks; the same mechanical properties that provide them with "embodied intelligence" also limit their dexterity and prevent them from handling relevant payloads. Robot designers also lack the tools necessary to optimize actuation of the effectively infinite degrees of freedom of soft continuum robots. Moreover, given the wide variety of manipulation tasks that people might want a soft robot to perform, we argue that an interactive human-in-the-loop design process could achieve the most useful designs. The goal of this project was to integrate novel soft robot mechanisms, computational design tools, and an interactive design methodology in order to create ubiquitous soft robots that seamlessly integrate into human homes and provide needed assistance.


In this project, we successfully designed new soft robot manipulator systems that have the potential to provide key manipulation capabilities both inside and outside the home. We developed a method for stiffening soft robot manipulators to allow them to accomplish a wider variety of tasks and achieve varied shapes. We created a newset of interaction paradigms between a human and a remote soft-growing robot manipulator, with demonstrations in both real and simulated scenarios. We enabled extrinsic manipulation in contact-rich environments using a library of robust short-horizon, goal-conditioned primitive policies, along with a framework to compose state constraints stemming from contacts specifications of each primitive. We also developed pneumatic platforms and control methods that enable flying soft robot manipulators to extend human reach. We also built cognitive systems for human-robot interaction, including predictive models for human indoor navigation and manipulation.


Intellectual Merit:This project integrated mechanical design, computational design, modeling, planning, and control to create novel soft robots and a methodology to improve and expand access to robot design. By combining advantages of both soft and rigid manipulators, the resulting novel 3D manipulators have unprecedented capabilities related to activities of daily living. This work was enabled by the combined expertise of PI Okamura (soft robot design and human-robot interaction) and co-I Liu (computer animation, physics simulation, and optimal control).


Broader Impacts:This project leads to impacts on human health and quality of life by (1) assisting people with limited physical abilities in their homes, (2) lowering the cost of robot manipulators, toward making ubiquitous robots accessible to a wide spectrum of users, and (3) promoting human safety through controllable mechanical compliance and robustness. The results have been disseminated via educational resources, demonstration of new soft robot capabilities, and open-source software. Outreach programs, public lab tours, and mentoring of graduate students, undergraduates, and high school students have broadened participation in engineering.
